item.title: Heading to Pycon 2024
item.author: Mackenzie Morgan
item.description:
PyCon US is going to be in my hometown this year! I don’t live there anymore, but it’ll be a nice chance to spend a weekend in downtown Pittsburgh, sort of playing tourist. (I think we can all guess that visiting my parents in the suburbs is nothing like “playing tourist,” right?)

I’m looking forward to getting to see one of my coworkers again. I met him last year at the Code BEAM Lite Mexico City, and he said he’s going to be bringing his mom to PyCon this year. I made them a list of touristy things to do in Pittsburgh. The one problem with remote work is that I rarely get to see my coworkers. I like the balance where some companies have annual off-sites, but I don’t work at one of those. I’ve only met my coworkers by means of personal travel.

item.title: Reusable Django Admin Filters
item.author: Mackenzie Morgan
item.description:
It’s fairly common to have a many-to-many connection to a User model. But sometimes, you have a lot of users in that table.

Problem 1: relations to large tables are unwieldy

If we let the Django Admin load every single user into the dropdown in the Django Admin, it’s unusable. The dropdowns are too long. The page takes too long to load. We need to filter it in advance.

item.title: Django Admin color picker
item.author: Mackenzie Morgan
item.description: When I add a new model to the Django app at work, I try to make sure the results in the Django admin have good usability, too. Just because it’ll be mainly developers (and a few project managers) seeing it doesn’t mean I can neglect usability. Consequently, I spend some time on hacking the Django admin. My manager says I’ve been making it do things he didn’t even realize were possible.
